Legal_Issue: Credibility, plausibility, and internal flight alternative findings
Application_Facts: Applicants claimed persecution by wife's family in Pakistan; inconsistencies in testimony; lack of subjective fear; existence of internal flight alternative in Rawalpindi or Kasur
Court_Ruling: Application for judicial review dismissed; no certification question
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged persecution by wife's family in Pakistan
Legal_Standard: Reasonable assessment of credibility and plausibility; existence of internal flight alternative
Applicable_Legislation: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, subsection 72(1)
Credibility_Assessment: Board found inconsistencies in testimony and lack of subjective fear; erred in dismissing uncle's affidavit
Legal_Provision_Cited: Subsection 72(1) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessed: Affidavit of uncle, lack of corroborative documents
Governing_Rule: Board must assess credibility and plausibility reasonably and determine if an IFA exists
Outcome: Refugee claims denied due to credible IFA despite errors in credibility assessment
Cause_Description: Persecution by wife's family in Pakistan
Evidence_Handling: Uncle's affidavit dismissed; corroboration not sufficiently considered
Evidence_Issues: Overemphasis on lack of documents; dismissal of affidavit
Legal_Provision: Subsection 72(1), Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony, viability of internal flight alternative
Decision_Rationale: Valid internal flight alternative in Rawalpindi or Kasur supports rejection of claim despite credibility errors
Evidentiary_Issues: Insufficient weight given to affidavit; overreliance on documentary gaps
Legal_Standard_Applied: Reasonable assessment of credibility, plausibility, and internal flight alternative
